Award.AwardTitle: Development of Electrochemical Mass Spectrometry for the Study of Protein Redox Chemistry and Protein Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program in the Division of Chemistry and the Molecular Biophysics Program from the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Dr. Hao Chen and his group at Ohio University are developing powerful new analytical tools for the fundamental study of protein chemistry, with long-term aims of probing protein functions in living cells and organisms. The study seeks new methods for rapid elucidation of protein structures and insights into the mechanisms of electrochemical reactions involving proteins. The work provides research opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students, including members of underrepresented groups. Dr. Chen is also actively involved in educational outreach activities, including ChemShows/Workshops/Seminars for pre-college students to learn about modern instrumental analysis and to develop enthusiasm for scientific research.

In this project, Dr. Chen's group is combining mass spectrometry (MS) and electrochemistry (EC) techniques for the study of protein redox reactions. The aim is a powerful tool for identification of the protein electrochemical reaction products and intermediates. One specific target is to combine fast and selective cleavage of disulfide bond linkages in a protein (via electroreduction) with MS analysis to enable protein sequencing and disulfide bond mapping. The work is also probing biomolecular electron transfer pathways for increased understanding of cellular oxidative stress and similar phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrochemistry (EC) of large molecules such as proteins was not well explored in the past, due to lack of structure characterization capability of electrochemical tools. In this project, we proposed to combine high resolution mass spectrometry (MS) and EC to study protein redox chemistry. With this NSF support, one major achievement is the development of novel Coulometric mass spectrometry (CMS) method for absolute quantitation of peptides and proteins based on tyrosine/tryptophan residue oxidation, without the need of synthesizing expensive standards. This method would enable large scale protein quantitation in biological systems to facilitate disease study and treatment.  New EC/MS and LC/EC/MS instruments for protein structural analysis and quantitative analysis, and elucidation of various electrochemical, organometallic and photochemical reaction mechanisms were also home built in our laboratories. Till now 23 research papers have been published in peer-reviewed journal articles such as JASMS, Anal. Chem., Chemical Science, JACS, Angewandte, and Nature Communications.

With this grant support, 6 PhD students and 2 Master students were trained for their dissertation/thesis study. Furthermore, 4 visiting professors and 15 undergrad students were trained with this NSF-supported project. They were not only introduced to MS field, but also learned about ion chemistry, electrochemistry, and bioanalysis. These scholars and students were encouraged to write manuscripts and to give oral or poster presentations in local, regional and national conferences such as ACS, ASMS, MUACC, EAS, Lake Arrowhead Ion Chemistry Meeting and Ohio Valley MS Symposium. These students got hand-on experiences in running mass spectrometers, designing and constructing new devices, and thinking independently for how to solve problems. Two PhD students won the Graduate Award from Eastern Analytical Symposium (EAS), a competitive recognition for students in our field. 5 undergraduate students coauthored papers with us. Many of these undergrads went to graduate/medical schools after graduation. Besides the involvement of students for research, some latest research results from this project were introduced to students in class and aroused substantial amounts of interests.

The PI participated in various outreach activities for pre-college student education. For instance, PI and graduate students attended the local Science Fair as judges. We had face-to-face discussions with many middle and high school students and provided them suggestions in their projects involving chemical measurements such as vitamin analysis in orange juice. Furthermore, PI frequently hosted student and guest visitors to tour our new lab at NJIT. During their visit, they got to know about MS and learned of the impact of analytical chemistry in our lives. In addition, PI and students also gave seminars about these NSF-sponsor research results and guest lectures in various conferences and universities.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2021
Modified by: Hao Chen
